<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
GROCERY
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/03/20/grocery-suppliers-workers-push-meet-surging-demand?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
When the Milk Aisle Becomes a Minefield
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Hospital-style shopping cart" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yOTUvaG9zcGl0YWxfc2hvcHBpbmdfY2FydC5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Yesterday, New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo <a href="https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/tasneemnashrulla/new-york-cuomo-order-stay-at-home-coronavirus?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">ordered all "nonessential" businesses</a> to institute mandatory work from home for 100% of their workforces. That means everyone from CPAs to “<img src="https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/240/google/223/round-pushpin_1f4cd.png" class="img-responsive" width="18" style="width:100% !important;max-width: 18px;" alt=""> nyc | content creators” will be joining the fun of no-pants all-hands.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">But who counts as essential?</strong> The heroes working in healthcare, public transportation, and grocery stores—further evidence that the battlegrounds in the fight against this pandemic are first the hospitals...then the frozen food aisles.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture: </strong>While those who’ve ransacked grocery stores can go home to their 124-pack of Charmin, the 2+ million Americans working in supermarkets must <a href="https://www.cnn.com/2020/03/19/business/states-grocery-workers-emergency-trnd/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">report to the frontlines</a> daily. And the <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/20/business/coronavirus-grocery-stores-workers.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">hardest part</a> of their jobs aside from staying healthy while manning a revolving door of strangers? Keeping shelves stocked.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Read this before you buy that 12th can of beans</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Empty aisles might make it seem like there’s a food shortage in the U.S. But America’s meat, vegetable, and pantry staples providers will be the first to tell you there isn’t—there’s just a logistics crunch.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Because COVID-19 took us by surprise. </strong>While the grocery supply chain is carefully calibrated to stock stores with just enough of what they need, not even Amazon’s algorithms could predict this unprecedented fear-fueled buying.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>“We do not see a supply shock in the sense of the availability,” said one UN economist to Bloomberg. “But there could be a </span><span><a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-03-19/the-fragile-system-supplying-food-to-the-world-is-under-strain?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">supply shock</a></span><span> in terms of logistics, not being able to move it from point A to point B.”</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The good news? Producers are already rejiggering strategies to solve for eggs.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Plants that once made items exclusively for (now-mostly closed) restaurants and school cafeterias have </span><span><a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/the-food-supply-u-s-has-a-lot-the-outbreak-makes-moving-it-tricky-11584631411?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">pivoted to supply</a></span><span> grocery stores.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Many producers are rerouting trucking fleets, keeping plants open overtime and on weekends, and hiring temp workers.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>some retailers expect panic-buying to <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/15/business/coronavirus-food-shortages.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">come in waves</a>. Now that suppliers and grocers better understand how we’re mainlining packaged chicken breasts, they might be able to keep pace the next time around.</p>

<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
MEDIA
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/03/20/streaming-companies-cut-speeds-europe-traffic-spikes?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
ScarJo Is Still Made from Porcelain in Standard Def
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="TVs showing streaming platforms" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yOTMvc3RyZWFtaW5nX2NvbXBhbmllcy5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Amazon Prime Video, Netflix, and YouTube are intentionally <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-03-20/amazon-netflix-cut-europe-s-stream-quality-to-ease-networks?srnd=premium&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">cutting streaming quality</a> across Europe to make sure the internet doesn't collapse under the pressure of tens of millions suddenly working from home, schooling from home, and vegging from home.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The rationale: </strong>Grainy Steve Harrington is bad, but no Steve Harrington is worse. Concerned the network infrastructure can’t handle the spike in traffic, EU officials have talked with streamers about taking things down a notch <a href="https://www.theverge.com/2020/3/20/21187930/youtube-reduces-streaming-quality-european-union-coronavirus-bandwidth-internet-traffic?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">to avoid internet congestion</a>.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Netflix is reducing bit rates for a month, which should reduce traffic on European networks by about 25%. Amazon is using a similar tack.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>YouTube is putting all European traffic on standard definition by default for 30 days. That could cut the data required to stream video by over half.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture: </strong>Not all users will need to <a href="https://www.ft.com/content/70333747-f180-4887-8a26-27ab6b230299?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">experience lower streaming quality</a>. But everyone needs the internet. Knowing most home connections are second-string JV compared to the <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/16/technology/coronavirus-working-from-home-internet.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">enterprise-grade internet service</a> at workplaces and schools, government officials are taking preemptive steps to make sure we don’t break the only thing keeping us sane during social distancing.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">+ Want to know how else Big Tech is handling COVID-19?</strong> <a href="https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/instagram-vs-reality-coronavirus-how-social-media-handles/id1480059697?i=1000468954332&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Listen to this episode</a> of Morning Brew’s <em>Business Casual</em> podcast.</p>

<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
POLITICS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/03/20/senators-dismiss-criticism-stock-sales?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Senators Dismiss Criticism Over Stock Sales
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Sen. Richard Burr" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yOTYvc2VuX3JpY2hhcmRfYnVyci5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Sen. Richard Burr. Bill Clark / Getty</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">When you time the market right, you brag about it to your friends. When elected officials time the market right, people get suspicious.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Thursday night, ProPublica published an <a href="https://www.propublica.org/article/senator-dumped-up-to-1-6-million-of-stock-after-reassuring-public-about-coronavirus-preparedness?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">investigation</a> showing that Senator Richard Burr, the Republican chair of the Senate Intelligence Committee, sold between $628,000 and $1.7 million worth of stock holdings on Feb. 13.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Why that looks sketchy:</strong><strong style="color:#000"></strong></p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>The market began its downward spiral just a week later. And around that time the Trump administration was downplaying the threat of the coronavirus in the U.S. even as Burr reportedly </span><span><a href="https://www.npr.org/2020/03/19/818192535/burr-recording-sparks-questions-about-private-comments-on-covid-19?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">raised the alarm</a></span><span> in private.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Burr isn’t the only official under the microscope. Three other U.S. senators, including Republican Kelly Loeffler of Georgia and Democrat Dianne Feinstein of California, began selling hundreds of thousands in stocks in late January.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The response from the senators:</strong> We did absolutely <a href="https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-03-20/senators-sold-stock-after-coronavirus-briefings-in-january?srnd=premium&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">nothing wrong</a>. Yesterday, Burr invited an ethics probe and Loeffler said her investment decisions are made by “multiple third-party advisors without my or my husband’s knowledge or involvement.” Loeffler’s husband is the chairman of the New York Stock Exchange.</p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
OPTIMISM
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/03/20/brew-readers-share-positive-stories-local-communities?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
People Are Good Pt. 3,143
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">All week, Brew readers have been writing in with inspiring stories of people working together to help those affected by the pandemic. We compiled this list to a) make you smile and b) give you ideas about ways to mobilize your own community. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Stephanie:</strong> “To keep a local florist afloat, members of my community are sending each other bouquets. Once you have a bouquet sent to you, you send a bouquet to another friend, and then they send a bouquet to someone else, and on and on.”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Riley in NYC:</strong> “Sauce Pizzeria is delivering free pizzas to hospitals every day, giving you the opportunity to donate a pizza and they'll match it.”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Perry in Reunion, CO:</strong> “A Facebook page was started in our community called ‘I Need This!’ It’s a place for community members to connect and help each other. Some people reached out because they need groceries, so there are others that go deliver what they need.”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bridget in Portland, OR:</strong> “I want to give a shout out to Trophy Cupcakes in Seattle. If you order cupcakes for delivery to non-profits, underserved communities and others in need, they’ll pay it forward when they’re back on their feet.”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Pat in CA: </strong>“A neighbor printed a flyer and offered to bring food and supplies to seniors in the neighborhood. She put her two small children in a wagon and put the flyers in the mailboxes of her neighbors.”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Brew Crew: </strong>We put together a <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/03/20/ways-help-coronavirus-epidemic?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">comprehensive list</a> of ways you can volunteer and donate to help people affected by COVID-19. Please read and share.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">And let's keep the positive stories comin’ by <a href="https://morningbrewdaily.typeform.com/to/yeQD9C?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">clicking here</a>.</p>

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">We know, everything you read in the news these days seems like a Saturday Headline. But there were some uniquely bizarre stories that came out this week. See if you can spot the one we made up. </p>
<ol>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>“OKZoomer is a </span><span><a href="https://www.rollingstone.com/culture/culture-news/coronavirus-covid-19-pandemic-dating-service-okzoomer-967836/?fbclid=IwAR1NPG0teMgR0dABiTGtZwVTRtp9IlTUeiFkwo5vHFWXfXVToEQiMCU0NJc&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">new dating service</a></span><span> for quarantined college kids”</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>“TV medical dramas give their masks to hospitals to </span><span><a href="https://ew.com/tv/coronavirus-masks-resident/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">help fight</a></span><span> the coronavirus”</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>“Baltimore mayor </span><span><a href="https://baltimore.cbslocal.com/2020/03/18/we-need-those-beds-baltimore-mayor-urges-people-to-put-down-guns-after-violence-continues-during-covid-19-pandemic/?fbclid=IwAR0_Egwn0LVkzGXbi-E-rj93r_jJGsoVStZIOYe7bO8GvvpAs5Qj4UUsa2w&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">begs residents</a></span><span><span> to stop shooting each other so hospital beds can be used for coronavirus patients”</span></span><span>
</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span><span>“Astronauts on the International Space Station <a href="https://media.giphy.com/media/qvfKpfZXvADxS/giphy.gif?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">delay return to Earth</a>: 'Our quarantine has a better view'" </span></span></li>

<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">To celebrate World Poetry Day</strong>, we wanted to leave you this Saturday with a message of hope. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0"><span>"Today" by Billy Collins</span></h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><span>If ever there were a spring day so perfect,<br></span>so uplifted by a warm intermittent breeze</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">that it made you want to throw<br>open all the windows in the house</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">and unlatch the door to the canary's cage,<br>indeed, rip the little door from its jamb,</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">a day when the cool brick paths<br>and the garden bursting with peonies</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">seemed so etched in sunlight<br>that you felt like taking</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">a hammer to the glass paperweight<br>on the living room end table,</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">releasing the inhabitants<br>from their snow-covered cottage</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">so they could walk out,<br>holding hands and squinting</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">into this larger dome of blue and white,<br>well, today is just that kind of day.</p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</th>
</tr>
</table>

#1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eworst week\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e since 2008. With stocks closing below where they were on Inauguration Day, the “Trump Bump” is \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/20/business/stock-market-today-coronavirus.html?action=click\u0026module=Spotlight\u0026pgtype=Homepage\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eofficially over\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eStimulus: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cspan\u003eOn Capitol Hill, the race is on to save the economy. Senate leaders were working on a \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/d7095f08b0a7cc584850030761d5558f?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e$1+ trillion rescue package\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cspan\u003e they hope to send to the House on Monday. There will be long nights ahead.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/th\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c!--[if !mso ]\u003e\u003c! -- --\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- \u003c![endif]--\u003e\n\u003c!-- END MARKETS --\u003e\n\u003c!-- ARTICLE ---\u003e\n\u003c!--[if !mso ]\u003e\u003c! -- --\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"c6 \" style=\"margin-bottom:7px\"\u003e\n\u003c!-- \u003c![endif]--\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003cth class=\"card\" style=\"text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px\"\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding: 15px;\"\u003e\n\u003ch3 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0\"\u003e\nGROCERY\n\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px\"\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/03/20/grocery-suppliers-workers-push-meet-surging-demand?email={{profile.email}}\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nWhen the Milk Aisle Becomes a Minefield\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Hospital-style shopping cart\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yOTUvaG9zcGl0YWxfc2hvcHBpbmdfY2FydC5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eFrancis Scialabba\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eYesterday, New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo \u003ca href=\"https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/tasneemnashrulla/new-york-cuomo-order-stay-at-home-coronavirus?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eordered all \"nonessential\" businesses\u003c/a\u003e to institute mandatory work from home for 100% of their workforces. That means everyone from CPAs to “\u003cimg src=\"https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/240/google/223/round-pushpin_1f4cd.png\" class=\"img-responsive\" width=\"18\" style=\"width:100% !important;max-width: 18px;\" alt=\"\"\u003e nyc | content creators” will be joining the fun of no-pants all-hands.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBut who counts as essential?\u003c/strong\u003e The heroes working in healthcare, public transportation, and grocery stores—further evidence that the battlegrounds in the fight against this pandemic are first the hospitals...then the frozen food aisles.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture: \u003c/strong\u003eWhile those who’ve ransacked grocery stores can go home to their 124-pack of Charmin, the 2+ million Americans working in supermarkets must \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2020/03/19/business/states-grocery-workers-emergency-trnd/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ereport to the frontlines\u003c/a\u003e daily. And the \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/20/business/coronavirus-grocery-stores-workers.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ehardest part\u003c/a\u003e of their jobs aside from staying healthy while manning a revolving door of strangers? Keeping shelves stocked.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eRead this before you buy that 12th can of beans\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eEmpty aisles might make it seem like there’s a food shortage in the U.S. But America’s meat, vegetable, and pantry staples providers will be the first to tell you there isn’t—there’s just a logistics crunch.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBecause COVID-19 took us by surprise. \u003c/strong\u003eWhile the grocery supply chain is carefully calibrated to stock stores with just enough of what they need, not even Amazon’s algorithms could predict this unprecedented fear-fueled buying.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e“We do not see a supply shock in the sense of the availability,” said one UN economist to Bloomberg. “But there could be a \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-03-19/the-fragile-system-supplying-food-to-the-world-is-under-strain?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esupply shock\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e in terms of logistics, not being able to move it from point A to point B.”\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe good news? Producers are already rejiggering strategies to solve for eggs.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003ePlants that once made items exclusively for (now-mostly closed) restaurants and school cafeterias have \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/the-food-supply-u-s-has-a-lot-the-outbreak-makes-moving-it-tricky-11584631411?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003epivoted to supply\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e grocery stores.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eMany producers are rerouting trucking fleets, keeping plants open overtime and on weekends, and hiring temp workers.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003esome retailers expect panic-buying to \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2020/03/15/business/coronavirus-food-shortages.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecome in waves\u003c/a\u003e. Now that suppliers and grocers better understand how we’re mainlining packaged chicken breasts, they might be able to keep pace the next time around.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAmazon Prime Video, Netflix, and YouTube are intentionally \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-03-20/amazon-netflix-cut-europe-s-stream-quality-to-ease-networks?srnd=premium\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecutting streaming quality\u003c/a\u003e across Europe to make sure the internet doesn't collapse under the pressure of tens of millions suddenly working from home, schooling from home, and vegging from home.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe rationale: \u003c/strong\u003eGrainy Steve Harrington is bad, but no Steve Harrington is worse. Concerned the network infrastructure can’t handle the spike in traffic, EU officials have talked with streamers about taking things down a notch \u003ca href=\"https://www.theverge.com/2020/3/20/21187930/youtube-reduces-streaming-quality-european-union-coronavirus-bandwidth-internet-traffic?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eto avoid internet congestion\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eNetflix is reducing bit rates for a month, which should reduce traffic on European networks by about 25%. Amazon is using a similar tack.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eYouTube is putting all European traffic on standard definition by default for 30 days. That could cut the data required to stream video by over half.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture: \u003c/strong\u003eNot all users will need to \u003ca href=\"https://www.ft.com/content/70333747-f180-4887-8a26-27ab6b230299?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eexperience lower streaming quality\u003c/a\u003e. But everyone needs the internet. Richard Burr\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yOTYvc2VuX3JpY2hhcmRfYnVyci5qcGciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eSen. Richard Burr. Bill Clark / Getty\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWhen you time the market right, you brag about it to your friends. When elected officials time the market right, people get suspicious.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThursday night, ProPublica published an \u003ca href=\"https://www.propublica.org/article/senator-dumped-up-to-1-6-million-of-stock-after-reassuring-public-about-coronavirus-preparedness?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003einvestigation\u003c/a\u003e showing that Senator Richard Burr, the Republican chair of the Senate Intelligence Committee, sold between $628,000 and $1.7 million worth of stock holdings on Feb. 13.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhy that looks sketchy:\u003c/strong\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eThe market began its downward spiral just a week later. And around that time the Trump administration was downplaying the threat of the coronavirus in the U.S. even as Burr reportedly \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.npr.org/2020/03/19/818192535/burr-recording-sparks-questions-about-private-comments-on-covid-19?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eraised the alarm\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e in private.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eBurr isn’t the only official under the microscope. Three other U.S. senators, including Republican Kelly Loeffler of Georgia and Democrat Dianne Feinstein of California, began selling hundreds of thousands in stocks in late January.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe response from the senators:\u003c/strong\u003e We did absolutely \u003ca href=\"https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-03-20/senators-sold-stock-after-coronavirus-briefings-in-january?srnd=premium\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003enothing wrong\u003c/a\u003e. Yesterday, Burr invited an ethics probe and Loeffler said her investment decisions are made by “multiple third-party advisors without my or my husband’s knowledge or involvement.” Loeffler’s husband is the chairman of the New York Stock Exchange.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAll week, Brew readers have been writing in with inspiring stories of people working together to help those affected by the pandemic. We compiled this list to a) make you smile and b) give you ideas about ways to mobilize your own community. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eStephanie:\u003c/strong\u003e “To keep a local florist afloat, members of my community are sending each other bouquets. Once you have a bouquet sent to you, you send a bouquet to another friend, and then they send a bouquet to someone else, and on and on.”\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eRiley in NYC:\u003c/strong\u003e “Sauce Pizzeria is delivering free pizzas to hospitals every day, giving you the opportunity to donate a pizza and they'll match it.”\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003ePerry in Reunion, CO:\u003c/strong\u003e “A Facebook page was started in our community called ‘I Need This!’ It’s a place for community members to connect and help each other. Some people reached out because they need groceries, so there are others that go deliver what they need.”\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBridget in Portland, OR:\u003c/strong\u003e “I want to give a shout out to Trophy Cupcakes in Seattle. If you order cupcakes for delivery to non-profits, underserved communities and others in need, they’ll pay it forward when they’re back on their feet.”\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003ePat in CA: \u003c/strong\u003e“A neighbor printed a flyer and offered to bring food and supplies to seniors in the neighborhood. She put her two small children in a wagon and put the flyers in the mailboxes of her neighbors.”\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBrew Crew: \u003c/strong\u003eWe put together a \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/03/20/ways-help-coronavirus-epidemic?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecomprehensive list\u003c/a\u003e of ways you can volunteer and donate to help people affected by COVID-19.
